author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: Harry Will Attend Philip’s Funeral, Raising Hope Royal Rift Will Heal
description: Although Harry  will come home to mourn with the family, his pregnant wife Meghan will not. The patriarch’s death opens an uncertain chapter for the House of Windsor.
content: LONDON — Buckingham Palace said on Saturday that Prince Harry would be returning to Britain for Prince Philip’s funeral next weekend, setting in motion fevered speculation about whether the reunion would mend fences in the royal family or sow deeper discord.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Darian Symoné Harvin
title: YungBBQ Can Be Almost Anyone. Just Watch.
description: Alexis Feacher, 21, built a following by creating freestyle dance routines emulating a specific era of pop culture.
content: Alexis Feacher, 21, has built a following with her freestyle dance impersonations of pop cultural figures and fictional characters. Her improvised movements and elaborate costumes have helped her convey the essence of Tina Turner, Jimmy Neutron, Missy Elliott and so many more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: The Force That Can Help Amazon’s Workers? Amazon’s Shoppers.
description: Customers can start telling Jeff Bezos to treat his workers like human beings.
content: Here are some of the ways that people who have worked inside Amazon’s warehouses describe the experience: “The job crushed my spirit and crippled my body.” “The lowest point in my life.” An “isolating colony of hell.” “They’re killing people mentally and physically.” “I began to hate my day-to-day life.” “The way Amazon pushes people is not moral.” “I had whole days where I didn’t talk to anyone.” “The systematic devaluing of human bodies.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edmund Lee
title: The Wall Street Journal’s Internal Audit
description: A look at what the newsroom’s internal study — The Content Review — concluded about the paper’s faults.
content: For over a year, a special team of editors within The Wall Street Journal analyzed the state of the newsroom and produced a detailed, lengthy report on what the paper is doing right, and, more important, what the paper is doing wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: ‘Maximum Pressure’ on Iran Has Failed
description: A return to the nuclear deal is the first step out of the morass.
content: There exists now a brief window of time for Iran and the United States to return to the principles of the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action, known to supporters and critics alike as the Iran nuclear deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: By 5-4 Vote, Supreme Court Lifts Restrictions on Prayer Meetings in Homes
description: The court shifted direction in cases on Covid-related limits on religious services after Justice Amy Coney Barrett replaced Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court late Friday night lifted California’s restrictions on religious gatherings in private homes, saying they could not be enforced to bar prayer meetings, Bible study classes and the like. The court’s brief, unsigned order followed earlier ones striking down limits on attendance at houses of worship meant to combat the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: Staying Afloat as Interest Rates Rise
description: The low rates that propelled the stock market’s boom are starting to rise, putting investors in a precarious position.
content: The stock market’s rally during the pandemic has been nothing short of amazing. But rising interest rates are raising the question of how long this bull market can last.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Rosenberg
title: A Teacher Marched to the Capitol. When She Got Home, the Fight Began.
description: Kristine Hostetter was a beloved fourth-grade teacher. Then came the pandemic, the election and the Jan. 6 riot in Washington.
content: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif. — Word got around when Kristine Hostetter was spotted at a public mask-burning at the San Clemente pier, and when she appeared in a video sitting onstage as her husband spoke at a QAnon convention. People talked when she angrily accosted a family wearing masks near a local surfing spot, her granddaughter in tow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Yuhas
title: A Soviet ‘Lord of the Rings’ Is Unearthed, Epic in Its Own Way
description: Tolkien fans received an unexpected gift with the rediscovery of an all-but-forgotten 1991 production. They were also left with questions, like “why is Gollum wearing a lettuce on his head?”
content: The hobbits and elves are familiar, if the Soviet folk-rock is not. One man is clearly a wizard, though the special effects are, at their best, not very good. And the growl of an actor painted green does sound — sort of — like he might be saying “gollum.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Essence of Spring
description: Make an herby salad, a bright pasta or a fresh one-pan meal to conjure flavors of the season.
content: Looking for a bright and zesty dish that conjures the essence of spring? This herby, crunchy salad with egg and walnuts from David Tanis (above) fits the bill, and it was our most popular recipe of the week. Kay Chun’s pasta Bolognese with lamb and peas is equally springy, as are Melissa Clark’s one-pan pork chops with feta, snap peas and mint. Or try your hand at some classic French baking: David Tanis’s baba au rhum and Claire Saffitz’s croissants caught New York Times Cooking readers’ attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Life Has Moved On, but Fans in Atlanta Mourn the All-Star Game
description: Friday’s home opener offered some prepandemic-like excitement, but even fans who support M.L.B.’s choice to move the signature event are sad to see it go.
content: ATLANTA — In and around Truist Park in suburban Atlanta on Friday, there were scant clues that Major League Baseball’s 2021 All-Star Game, as of roughly a week ago, was supposed to be held here on July 13.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Maria Cramer
title: Black Army Medic Pepper-Sprayed in Traffic Stop Accuses Officers of Assault
description: Second Lt. Caron Nazario was in uniform when two Windsor, Va., police officers ordered him to stop his car, pointed their weapons at him and doused him with pepper spray.
content: Caron Nazario, a lieutenant in the U.S. Army Medical Corps, was driving to Petersburg, Va., from a drill weekend the night of Dec. 5 when he saw police lights flashing behind him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tirhakah Love
title: What DMX’s Poetry of Death Did for Hip-Hop
description: In life and art, death was never far from Earl Simmons.
content: If you’ve ever attended a DMX concert, it’s more than likely that you’ve seen him cry. As the adrenaline of the night would cool, the rapper born as Earl Simmons would pray, acting as the intercessor for the holy spirit on behalf of the audience, through a sheet of sweat and tears.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: We Asked Congress’s Freshmen to Give Up Stock Trading. Few Were Willing.
description: Playing individual stocks is a losing strategy more often than not, and it poses political risk. But only a handful of newly minted lawmakers saw it that way.
content: It’s easy to forget that just a year ago, senators from both parties were under Justice Department scrutiny for potentially profiteering from the coronavirus with well-timed stock trades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: The New Cancel Culture Capitalism
description: For Republicans, cancel culture is good for business.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your wrap-up of the week in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Quake Strikes Java in Indonesia, Killing at Least 6 People
description: Television reports showed people running in panic from malls and buildings in several cities in East Java Province. The earthquake shook the tourist hot spot of Bali.
content: MALANG, Indonesia — A strong earthquake killed at least six people and damaged buildings on Indonesia’s main island, Java, on Saturday and shook the tourist hot spot of Bali, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: A Hole in One Pushes Corey Conners Up the Masters Leaderboard
description: The shot by the Canadian golfer was the sixth hole in one on No. 6 in tournament history.
content: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The old man working near No. 2 knew. He had to have known, because everyone knew.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman and Mitch Smith
title: Michigan’s Virus Cases Are Out of Control, Putting Gov. Gretchen Whitmer in a Bind
description: Ms. Whitmer, a Democrat, locked down her state over the din of protests last year. Now she is trying a different approach, appealing to personal responsibility.
content: Nowhere in America is the coronavirus pandemic more out of control than in Michigan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: Sliding in the Polls, Erdogan Kicks Up a New Storm Over the Bosporus
description: As part of a push to carve a canal alongside the waterway, Turkey’s president signaled that he could scrap a treaty that has kept peace in the region for decades.
content: ISTANBUL — The unpredictable roller coaster that has become Turkish politics was on full display this past week after 104 retired admirals publicly challenged President Recep Tayyip Erdogan in an open letter — and 10 of them ended up in jail, accused of plotting a coup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Merger Mania
description: Dick Shlakman and Will Nediger join forces in a friendly takeover.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This is a really neat, busy grid by a couple of wags: Will Nediger, a familiar name, constructs professionally, and Dick Shlakman, who had a couple of puzzles some years ago (including a Sunday), is a retired lawyer and corporate executive. Mr. Shlakman is somewhat the senior of the two (by five decades, give or take) and came up with the business-y theme, probably from all those years of watching every company in our frenetic capitalist society try to beat or join every other company. Perhaps, then, Mr. Nediger is to blame for the cascade of interesting fill, some of which I incorrectly attributed to the theme. All in all, a good challenge that deals with the acquisitive and rewards the inquisitive (as always, forgive me).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Mets and Yankees are Both Shut Out in Frustrating Losses
description: Jacob deGrom tired a career-high in strikeouts for the Mets but was outlasted by Miami’s Trevor Rodgers. The Yankees optioned Domingo German to their alternate site.
content: Jazz Chisholm Jr. watched Jacob deGrom’s first 100 mile-per-hour fastball whiz by and wasn’t impressed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Afghan President in ‘Desperate Situation’ as His Power Is Undermined
description: Ashraf Ghani has few remaining allies, the Taliban are gaining militarily and his international supporters are impatient with him and the stumbling peace process.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — He attends international conferences, meets with diplomats, recently inaugurated a dam and delivers patriotic speeches vowing to defend his country against the Taliban.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Douglas Martin
title: Ramsey Clark, Attorney General and Rebel With a Cause, Dies at 93
description: Mr. Clark oversaw the drafting of the Fair Housing Act in 1968 and went on to defend both the disadvantaged and the unpopular.
content: Ramsey Clark, who championed civil rights and liberties as attorney general in the Johnson administration, then devoted much of the rest of his life to defending unpopular causes and infamous people, including Saddam Hussein and others accused of war crimes, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: They Overcame Mutual Loathing, and Saved a Town
description: Environmentalists and loggers thought they had nothing in common, until they started talking.
content: JOHN DAY, Ore. — One of the most venomous battles in our polarized nation is the one that has unfolded between loggers and environmentalists in timber towns like this one in the snow-capped Blue Mountains of Eastern Oregon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pierre-Antoine Louis
title: A Love Letter to Black Women
description: A first solo exhibition by the Bahamian artist Gio Swaby aims to redefine the often politicized Black body.
content: For many, art provides a voice for the unheard. It can capture moments of positivity that might otherwise be unrepresented.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: 2 Salt Lake County Deputies Shot Outside Sheriff’s Office, Officials Say
description: The gunman was dead, Sheriff Rosie Rivera said, adding that the shooting happened after “some type of altercation.”
content: Two deputies were wounded — one shot in an eye and the other in the face — after “some type of altercation” outside the Salt Lake County Sheriff’s Office, the sheriff said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: To Speed Up, Some Call for Delaying Second Shots
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, April 10, 2021.
content: “Relying on one dose of Moderna or Pfizer to stop variants like B.1.351 is like using a BB gun to stop a charging rhino.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Wright
title: 5 Takeaways From the Second Week of the Derek Chauvin Trial
description: Witnesses addressed two key issues: What caused George Floyd’s death, and whether Mr. Chauvin violated police policies on the use of force.
content: The first week of the Derek Chauvin trial was marked by emotional accounts from bystanders who witnessed the nine and a half minutes that the police pinned George Floyd to the ground. But the second week struck a different chord, highlighting testimony from medical and law enforcement experts that centered on the conduct of Mr. Chauvin and the cause of Mr. Floyd’s death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: New Hampshire and Oklahoma are the latest states to open vaccinations to outside residents.
description: The moves come as President Biden pushed up the deadline to make all adults eligible for a vaccine and as the pace of inoculations is accelerating in the country.
content: New Hampshire and Oklahoma announced plans this week to open up vaccine eligibility to outside residents as supply grows and more states expand eligibility.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley, Rana F. Sweis and Eric Schmitt
title: Royal Rivalry Bares Social Tensions Behind Jordan’s Stable Veneer
description: The standoff between King Abdullah II and his half brother, Prince Hamzah, wasn’t just palace intrigue. It hinted at Saudi meddling and highlighted wider tensions within Jordan’s complex society.
content: AMMAN, Jordan — The prince and the general paced the garden outside the prince’s palace, locked in a deep argument. The prince was shouting, the general was barely audible. But the general made the threat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: After Snatching One Crown, Mrs. World Gives Up Her Own
description: Last year’s winner of a pageant for married women grabbed a crown from the 2021 Mrs. Sri Lanka winner, who she claimed was divorced, in violation of pageant rules.
content: Last year’s winner of Mrs. World, a beauty pageant for married women, said she would return her crown after she snatched one off the head of the 2021 winner of Mrs. Sri Lanka World, claiming that she was divorced — a violation of pageant rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Republicans Have Found Their Cruel New Culture War
description: Arkansas lawmakers’ move against trans people reflects a larger strategy.
content: Straight people have often asked me what I, a gay man, have in common with someone who’s trans. Gay people have often put that question to themselves. There are many answers. Here’s one: I know what it’s like to have my identity, my dignity — my very hold on happiness — pressed into partisan battle and fashioned into a political weapon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: At Last, Aid for Senior Nutrition That Offers More Than Crumbs
description: Meal programs for older adults have long been underfunded. The new economic recovery plan will help.
content: Long before the coronavirus hit, nutrition programs that served the nation’s older adults struggled to keep up with a growing demand. Often, they could not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edmund Lee
title: Inside the Fight for the Future of The Wall Street Journal
description: A special team led by a high-level manager says Rupert Murdoch’s paper must evolve to survive. But a rivalry between editor and publisher stands in the way.
content: The Wall Street Journal is a rarity in 21st-century media: a newspaper that makes money. A lot of money. But at a time when the U.S. population is growing more racially diverse, older white men still make up the largest chunk of its readership, with retirees a close second.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Eileen Sullivan
title: Young Migrants Crowd Shelters, Posing Test for Biden
description: The administration is under intensifying pressure to expand its capacity to care for as many as 35,000 unaccompanied minors, part of a wave of people crossing the border.
content: WASHINGTON — The desperate plea landed this week in the email inboxes of employees in government agencies like the Department of Homeland Security and NASA: Will you consider taking a four-month paid leave from your job to help care for migrant children in government-run shelters packed with new arrivals at the border?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Rose Holds Slim Masters Lead as Johnson Misses the Cut
description: After shooting a 75 on Friday, Dustin Johnson, who won the Masters in November, became the latest defending champion not to advance into the weekend.
content: AUGUSTA, Ga. — To most every player at the Masters Tournament, the 530-yard, water-guarded hole called Firethorn is a back-nine destination for earning back a stroke. To Bernd Wiesberger, that hole, No. 15 at Augusta National Golf Club, can teeter toward the nightmarish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher, Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Martin
title: Trump Lashes His Enemies Anew as G.O.P. Dances Around His Presence
description: A gathering of Republican leaders and top donors in Florida this weekend is less a reset of priorities and more a reminder of the tensions that Donald J. Trump instills in his party.
content: The first spring donor retreat after a defeat for a political party is typically a moment of reflection and renewal as officials chart a new direction forward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Marshall D. Sahlins, Groundbreaking Anthropologist, Dies at 90
description: His work focused on the way cultures shape, and are shaped by, individuals — a framework he demonstrated through his passionate political activism.
content: Marshall D. Sahlins, a brilliant and witty anthropologist who, starting in the 1970s, explored how individuals shape and are shaped by their cultures — a point he had already put in practice a decade earlier as the inventor of the “teach-in” against the Vietnam War — died on Monday at his home in Chicago. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon and Inyoung Kang
title: Seeing Hate, 28 Asian and Asian-American Photographers Focus on Love
description: In a special project by the Culture desk, artists respond to a climate of fear and racism with images and reflections from the heart.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Could Ron DeSantis Be Trump’s G.O.P. Heir? He’s Certainly Trying.
description: Florida’s governor has elbowed his way to the front of the line of 2024 Republican hopefuls by leveraging a brand of “competent Trumpism” (as one ally put it) and hitting back at critics of his pandemic leadership.
content: MIAMI — No one had to tell Ron DeSantis that his mock debates had bordered on disastrous. His answers rambled. He seemed uninspired.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Man Who Boasted He Was at Capitol Riot Is Charged in Bomb Plot
description: Seth Aaron Pendley was arrested on Thursday and charged with plotting to blow up an Amazon data center in Virginia, prosecutors said.
content: A Texas man who boasted that he was at the United States Capitol when a pro-Trump mob stormed the building in January has been charged with plotting to blow up an Amazon data center in Virginia, the Justice Department said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Weiss
title: She Gets Paid Just to Humiliate Her Fans
description: The high-priced hustle of financial domination, where “pay pigs” send tributes to their cash masters.
content: To celebrate her 27th birthday, Mistress Marley, a professional dominatrix from Harlem, flew to Tulum, Mexico, where she rented a modern four-bedroom villa with a limestone pool, private beach and personal chef.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango, Shaila Dewan and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Despite Other Factors, Police Caused Floyd’s Death, Medical Examiner Says
description: Dr. Andrew Baker, who performed the official autopsy of George Floyd, said that fentanyl and heart disease had contributed to his death, but that the officers’ actions were the main cause.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — In a trial where many key figures have spent hours on the stand, the prosecution whipped through one of their most anticipated witnesses, the doctor who performed George Floyd’s official autopsy, in a mere 50 minutes on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Can the Meritocracy Find God?
description: The secularization of America probably won’t reverse unless the intelligentsia gets religion.
content: As is now traditional on the Easter holiday, I spent last Sunday hunting for eggs with my children, attending Mass, hiding more eggs at an aunt’s house so the children could hunt yet again, and reading elegiac essays about American Christianity’s decline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Not So Intense, Say
description: Evans Clinchy throws a highly cultured Saturday brunch.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This kind of grid is my bread and butter, not just because so many of its entries make me think of a nice meal out, but because so many of its entries are completely unknown, absent from my knowledge. That makes for great column fodder, true, but it’s also so satisfying to suss out a little pileup of trivia like we see in the northeast corner, and I found the difficult cluing very likable and fresh.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Worthen
title: Medical School Needs a Dose of the Humanities
description: The horrors of Covid-19 may give proponents of the liberal arts an unexpected opening.
content: Over the past year, ordinary medical research nearly ground to a halt as researchers focused on coronavirus vaccine trials and treatments. Single-mindedness paid off. Drugmakers developed lifesaving vaccines in record time, and now a third of Americans are at least partially vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Dana Rubinstein
title: ‘Sense of Disappointment’ on the Left as the N.Y.C. Mayor’s Race Unfolds
description: Even as New York has veered toward the left, two more-moderate candidates, Andrew Yang and Eric Adams, lead the mayoral race.
content: Over the last year, New York politics have appeared to lurch ever leftward. First came the primary victories last summer in a series of House and state legislative races, then the legalization of recreational marijuana, and just this week, a state budget agreement that would raise taxes on the wealthy and create a $2.1 billion fund to aid undocumented workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: After Going ‘Free of L.G.B.T.,’ a Polish Town Pays a Price
description: Krasnik voted to be “free of L.G.B.T.” two years ago to satisfy conservative voters. Now, the mayor regrets the move, which has led to censure from other European countries and put funding at risk.
content: KRASNIK, Poland — When local councilors adopted a resolution two years ago declaring their small town in southeastern Poland “free of L.G.B.T.,” the mayor didn’t see much harm in what appeared to be a symbolic and legally pointless gesture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Turn the Lights Out. Here Come the Birds.
description: Buildings, landmarks and monuments are turning off lights to prevent fatal impacts as birds set off on spring migration.
content: Dozens of American cities are being transformed this spring, enveloped in darkness as the lights that usually brighten up their skylines are turned off at night to prevent birds from fatal impacts during their annual migrations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: China Fines Alibaba $2.8 Billion in Landmark Antitrust Case
description: The penalty is the biggest move to date in China’s campaign to tighten supervision of its internet Goliaths.
content: By hitting the e-commerce titan Alibaba with a record $2.8 billion antitrust fine on Saturday, Chinese officials sent a message to the country’s high-flying internet industry: We’ve got our eyes on you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon remind us about what’s really important before we all go interstellar.
content: ACROSTIC — Today’s passage concerns something that humanity has fixated on since its discovery by Galileo in the 17th century, yet it’s also very timely — Mars, the red planet, is hosting an elaborate group of mechanical explorers from Earth right now, in preparation for our imminent mass migration. That’s a stretch, but if you read the book excerpted in today’s puzzle, Kate Greene’s “Once Upon a Time I Lived on Mars,” you might feel a bit better about the possibility of visiting, maybe for a dinner out. Keep in mind that snacking on the way will present a logistical challenge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Michael Majchrowicz
title: Matt Gaetz Says He Is a Victim of ‘the Leaks and the Lies’ of Critics
description: The congressman defended himself in his first major public appearance since a Justice Department inquiry came to light last week.
content: Representative Matt Gaetz, the Florida Republican who is the focus of a Justice Department inquiry over whether he broke sex trafficking laws, maintained his innocence on Friday and insisted he was the victim of “the leaks and the lies” of his critics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Will Biden ‘Pack’ the Supreme Court?
description: The president has not explicitly endorsed calls to expand the court, but he just ordered a study exploring possible reforms.
content: For many liberals, the state of the nation’s courts system has reached a crisis point. For President Donald Trump and Senator Mitch McConnell, reshaping the judiciary branch was a top priority throughout Trump’s term — and they largely succeeded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Woman Who Coughed on Pier 1 Shopper’s Face Is Sentenced to 30 Days
description: Debra Hunter, 53, was seen in a widely circulated video last year coughing on a customer who was recording her dispute with employees at a home-goods store in Jacksonville, Fla.
content: A Florida woman who was seen in a widely watched video intentionally coughing on a shopper at a Pier 1 home-goods store last summer, as fears about the pandemic raged, was sentenced on Thursday to 30 days in jail, court records show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller and Denise Grady
title: AstraZeneca Vaccine and Blood Clots: What Is Known So Far
description: In rare cases, an immune reaction has led to antibodies that caused a serious clotting disorder. But public health experts maintain the vaccine’s benefits far outweigh the risks for most people.
content: The AstraZeneca-Oxford vaccine has been deployed against Covid-19 in at least 115 countries, some of them for several months now. But it wasn’t until a few cases of a rare blood-clotting disorder — some fatal — emerged within the past month or so that many European nations began to rethink its use across all age groups.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: ‘You Can’t Trust Anyone’: Russia’s Hidden Covid Toll Is an Open Secret
description: The country’s official coronavirus death toll is 102,649. But at least 300,000 more people died last year during the pandemic than were reported in Russia’s most widely cited official statistics.
content: SAMARA, Russia — She burst into the hospital morgue and the bodies were everywhere, about a dozen of them in black bags on stretchers. She headed straight for the autopsy room, pleading with the guard in a black jacket: “Can I speak to the doctor who opened up my father?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kulish
title: Why Buy a Yacht When You Can Buy a Newspaper?
description: Billionaires aren’t usually cast as saviors of democracy. But one way they are winning plaudits for civic-minded endeavors is by funding the Fourth Estate.
content: Billionaires have had a pretty good pandemic. There are more of them than there were a year ago, even as the crisis has exacerbated inequality. But scrutiny has followed these ballooning fortunes. Policymakers are debating new taxes on corporations and wealthy individuals. Even their philanthropy has come under increasing criticism as an exercise of power as much as generosity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Schwartz
title: John Topping, 77, Dies; Early Advocate for Climate Action
description: A former official of the Environmental Protection Agency, he was a Republican activist on global warming when it was an issue with bipartisan support
content: John Topping, whose work to warn the world of the risks of climate change stretched back to the 1980s, and who helped spur the international effort to limit warming, died on March 9 at a hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Doug Mills
title: Scenes From the First Rounds of the Masters
description: Our staff photographer Doug Mills brings us an inside look at Augusta National.
content: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Maybe it is the Masters tournament’s place as an annual rite of spring or its rich history, revisited this week for an 85th time. Perhaps it is because the tournament is the only major golf championship contested on the same golf course every year, which breeds a comforting familiarity. But the Masters stands out among sporting events — for its colorful grounds, for its gentle mix of old and new champions, and for the generations of attending families renewing traditions on the site. It is the rare athletic arena in the spotlight for only four days a year, but then maybe that is its ultimate charm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: Martina Batan, New York Art Dealer Consumed by a Cold Case, Dies at 62
description: Finding answers to the unsolved murder of her 14-year-old brother became a lifelong quest, ultimately chronicled in a documentary film.
content: One winter night in 1978, a 14-year-old boy named Jeffrey Batan was killed in Rego Park, Queens. His body was found with 20 stab wounds in a snowy yard the next morning. Though the violent crime received media attention, it was never solved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker and Evan Hill
title: Police Say an Antifa Activist Likely Shot at Officers. His Gun Suggests Otherwise.
description: Investigators said that Michael Reinoehl probably opened fire before officers killed him last year. But some key evidence raises questions about that conclusion.
content: SEATTLE — When a U.S. Marshals task force killed a self-described antifa activist in Washington State in September, the Trump administration applauded the removal of a “violent agitator” who was suspected of murder. Last week, local investigators concluded a monthslong homicide inquiry with the announcement that the activist, Michael Reinoehl, had most likely fired at authorities first, effectively justifying the shooting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: This Heroin-Using Professor Wants to Change How We Think About Drugs
description: Prof. Carl Hart saw drugs as destroyers of communities. Then he saw the positive side. “We have miseducated the public,” he said.
content: Carl L. Hart, a neuroscientist at Columbia University, fielded questions the other day about his new book, which makes an unconventional case for drug use.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
title: His Fence Says ‘Black Lives Matter.’ His City Says Paint Over It.
description: West St. Paul, Minn., says the nearly 75-foot message violates multiple portions of city code. The conflict is brewing as the Twin Cities region uneasily awaits a verdict in the Derek Chauvin trial.
content: The colorful mural, adorned with hearts, a portrait of a local activist and the words “Black Lives Matter,” stands out at a busy intersection in West St. Paul, a community nestled against the Twin Cities. It is a cherished symbol for many Black residents, a site of reflection and pride.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: A ‘San Diego Kid’ Gives the Padres Their First No-Hitter
description: Joe Musgrove allowed only one base runner, on a hit-by-pitch. San Diego had been the last team without a no-hitter.
content: Maybe it was fate, Joe Musgrove guessed late Friday night. How else to explain his sudden status as the first pitcher to throw a no-hitter in the history of his hometown team? Musgrove was drafted by Toronto, won a World Series with Houston and made an opening-day start for Pittsburgh. But his inner compass always pointed home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Do You Have to Pay Your Building’s Covid-19 Cleaning Fee?
description: It depends on how your contract is worded, but there is often room for negotiation in any case.
content: Q: I am moving out of the Yorkville apartment that I’ve been renting in a condo. The management company says the condo board has mandated a $1,250 Covid-19 cleaning fee, on top of the standard move-out fee. My lease included a rider stating that it was subject to the provisions and bylaws of the condo, but $1,250 seems like an absurd amount of money to clean a 650-square-foot apartment, and unnecessary when it’s been shown that surfaces are not high-risk. Do I have to pay this?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo and Danya Issawi
title: Focus on Wellness and Take a Gardening Class
description: This week, spend story time with the National Postal Museum, listen to a lecture from the artist Lorraine O’Grady or take a Syrian cooking class.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.

author: By Corinne Purtill
title: Companies Can’t Stop Overworking
description: Excess work isn’t good for anyone, employers included. So why are we still doing it?
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.

title: Incarcerated and Infected: How the Virus Tore Through the U.S. Prison System
description: Since March 2020, New York Times reporters have tracked every known coronavirus case in every correctional setting in the nation. More than 2,700 inmates have died.
content: Since March 2020, New York Times reporters have tracked every known coronavirus case in every correctional setting in the nation. More than 2,700 inmates have died.

title: The Oddities That Make the Masters Unique
description: The Masters Tournament, played annually at Augusta National Golf Club in Georgia, is one of the South’s grandest spring traditions. It also has its quirks.
content: The Masters Tournament, played annually at Augusta National Golf Club in Georgia, is one of the South’s grandest spring traditions. It also has its quirks.

author: By Reuters
title: Fans Mourn the Death of DMX
description: Fans created a small memorial in White Plains, N.Y., to remember the rapper and actor Earl Simmons, also known as DMX, who died on Friday.
content: Fans created a small memorial in White Plains, N.Y., to remember the rapper and actor Earl Simmons, also known as DMX, who died on Friday.

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: World Leaders Remember Prince Philip
description: Leaders from around the world paid tribute to the life and service of Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, who died on Friday, and offered condolences to Queen Elizabeth II and the royal family.
content: Leaders from around the world paid tribute to the life and service of Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, who died on Friday, and offered condolences to Queen Elizabeth II and the royal family.

author: By The New York Times
title: Video Shows Police Pepper-Spraying Black Army Medic at Traffic Stop
description: Caron Nazario, an Army lieutenant, was driving through Windsor, Va., on Dec. 5, 2020, when two officers drew guns and doused him with pepper spray, according to a lawsuit filed this month.
content: Caron Nazario, an Army lieutenant, was driving through Windsor, Va., on Dec. 5, 2020, when two officers drew guns and doused him with pepper spray, according to a lawsuit filed this month.

title: Corrections: April 10, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, April 10, 2021.
content: An article on Monday about an elite high school’s efforts to implement a coronavirus testing program, relying on outdated information from the Illinois Department of Public Health, misstated the status of its investigation into SafeGuard Screening. After publication, The Times was told that the investigation had ended in March, after SafeGuard received federal certification.
source.name: The New York Times
